messages: 6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:12): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4, re your latest email, what do you mean by "the HTML5 specification"?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:12): it's a noun, isn't it?
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:13): mkay, assuming you mean the one Hixie edits, I wonder how you're going to do it :)
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:14): oh, I'll make a copy and change it from there
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:14): no edit wars
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:14): But edit wars add drama to life!
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:14): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4, ah ok, makes sense
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:14): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I have accepted your feedback. I will reply with 4 months
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:15): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: Only four? Dude, you need to learn how to edit specs! :)
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:15): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: it says so right on there on my blog
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:15): oh wait, that's elementary web design
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:15): I get confused easily
e862bf3550c1ed74374b6cb7492e51f3 (16:15): think a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 life just exstended with 4month?
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:16): (edit wars works for me, but I believe only Hixie has write access to the source file so any changes would be overwritten each time the spec is generated)
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:16): Actually, I was looking at the source
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:17): and there are these comments saying "YOU MUST TALK TO IAN BEFORE CHANGING THIS TEXT"
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:17): I wonder who those are directed to
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:17): I decided they don't apply to me
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:17): That was because of changes made before publication to /TR/, I believe
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:17): W3C pubteam
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:18): I won't be taking feedback via the whatwg lists, so I have to change some parts
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:19): i wouldn't expect it to apply to forks anyway
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:19): that wouldn't make sense
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:20): but are you sure you're looking at the source?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:20): it might be a header file that had that
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:20): I don't think it would make sense, either
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:20): but... Please leave your sense of logic at the door, thanks!
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:23): yadayada
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:23): also, I need to update the spec to disallow private feedback on certain issues
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:23): basically anything controversial
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:24): I thought about trying to disallow it completely, but it seems like I would have to recuse myself from hallway conversations
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:24): not a credible way of going about things :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:24): "No, sorry, I can't accept your comment. Good bye."
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:25): on video codecs, that's exactly what I'll say
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:25): well, maybe "send your comment to the list" would be better, and a touch more polite
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:27): so you're saying you will no longer have hallway or lunch conversations on <video>?
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:27): sounds pretty tough
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:27): on codecs
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:28): there are plenty of other parts
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:29): In fact, I won't even discuss codecs here
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:29): only on the list
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:33): that is starting now or so?
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (16:34): doesn't really matter I suppose; anyway, I'm curious what your draft will look like
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:48): Someone should give me CVS access so I can make a version of the spec where all the letters are upside down
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (16:55): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that would be awesome!
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (16:56): or you could make all 'i's that Turkish cahracter that looks like 'i' but without the dot

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:05): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: Maybe I should replace them all with http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0D%0A%26%23x131%3B%3Cblink%3E%26%23x307%3B%3C%2Fblink%3E
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:05): except sadly that appears to be buggy in pretty much all browsers :-(
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:05): Firefox and IE on Windows ignore the styling of the dot entirely
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:06): Firefox on Linux doesn't even draw the dot

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:07): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4, re http://blog.mozilla.com/rob-sayre/2009/07/02/secrets/ - why are you surprised that Hixie accepts feedback that gets sent to him privately? That's certainly not the first time he's mentioned that and it would be silly for him to reject it
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (17:08): I am not surprised
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (17:08): no comment on the silliness
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:10): ok, then I'm not sure I get the point of what you're trying to say about it
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (17:12): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I can live with that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:15): wonders if it worth pointing out that we may be unable to get consensus on not specifying codecs, decides it is not
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:22): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, so we're damned if we do and damned if we don't? Cool!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:23): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: damn you.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:24): Why do people like Flash and <video> more than they like <embed>/<object> methods of embedding videos?
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (17:25): I think it's because they promise to "just work"

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:26): well, ignoring the fact that Flash uses object/embed, using object/embed for regular video files historically depends on 3rd party codecs that may not be present for all users
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:26): What should .min and .max return on an HTMLInputElement which doesn't allow min/max?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:26): whereas Flash already has sufficient market penetration for that problem to be ignorable
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:27): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, what does the spec say?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:27): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I can't find the spec saying anything.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:28): (wrt to this)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:29): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: undefined, no?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:29): Because you are doing a property lookup of a non-existent property
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:29): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: But the spec says min/max return a DOMString, so surely that's wrong?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:29): the spec says they should reflect the content attributes
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:30): Oh you mean in the case where min/max are supported but not relevant to that particular type of input
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:30): Yes
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:31): so my guess is that even though they don't apply to certain controls, should still return whatever values were specified (if any) or the default value if not
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:31): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Empty string then
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:31): (or the values that were supplied)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:31): From my reading of the spec they should return an empty string or what was given.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:31): There is no default value.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:32): The empty string is the deafult value
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:32): so we all agree
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:32): No need for anyone to get CVS access and modify the draft or anything
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (17:33): aw, you sound a little snarky :(
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (17:33): hope everything is ok :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:36): This is IRC, you're not allowed to be snarky in here!
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:37): won't dare get in the way of any Boojumic snarkiness, however
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:38): "The value DOM attribute is in mode filename." ‚Äî does that mean it only ever returns one?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:38): What does "in mode" mean?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:38): (quick, while b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea's away from his computer!)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:39): Oh, wait.
